title: 114_hr4191
content: The "United States Virgin Islands College Access Act of 2015" aims to establish a program for college-bound residents of the US Virgin Islands to have more choices among higher education institutions, including public school grants. The Governor awards grants to eligible institutions to cover the difference in tuition for in-State and out-of-State students, with a maximum amount of $10,000 per year and $50,000 in total. Payments are prorated for students attending eligible institutions. If funds are insufficient to award grants to all eligible students, the Governor will reduce payments first for students who haven't received funds before, then for all other eligible students. The Governor may adjust tuition and fee payments based on financial need and administrative burdens to avoid undue hardship. Further adjustments can be made based on income and need of eligible students. Eligible institution refers to a public four-year institution of higher education. (A) is a public four-year institution of higher education located in a State, the District of Columbia, Puerto Rico, or Guam; (B) is eligible for student financial assistance programs under title IV of the Higher Education Act of 1965; and (C) must enter into an agreement with the Governor, specifying terms including the requirement to use funds to supplement, not supplant, assistance for eligible students from the United States Virgin Islands. Eligible students from the United States Virgin Islands must meet specific criteria to qualify for assistance at an institution of higher education. This includes being domiciled in the US Virgin Islands for at least 12 consecutive months before starting college, graduating from a secondary school in the US Virgin Islands after January 1, 2013, and beginning undergraduate studies within three years. To qualify for assistance at an institution of higher education in the US Virgin Islands, eligible students must have completed a period of active duty in the Armed Forces, Peace Corps service, or service under the National and Community Service Act. They must also be enrolled at least half-time in a program leading to a recognized educational credential and maintain satisfactory progress. To qualify for assistance at an institution of higher education in the US Virgin Islands, eligible students must maintain satisfactory progress in their course of study, have the US Virgin Islands as their principal residence, and not have completed their first undergraduate baccalaureate course. The term "institution of higher education" refers to the definition in the Higher Education Act of 1965, and the term "Governor" refers to the Governor of the US Virgin Islands. The Act defines terms like "secondary school" and "Secretary" and states that institutions of higher education are not required to change admissions policies for eligible students. Students must apply for tuition payment, and the Governor administers the program. The Governor collaborates with the Secretary to implement the program and may partner with other entities for efficiency. Policies and procedures are developed in consultation with eligible higher education institutions. A Memorandum of Agreement is established between the Governor and the Secretary. The Governor consults with the Secretary on program administration and may receive technical assistance. The Governor reports annually to Congress on eligible students and grant awards. The Comptroller General of the United States will monitor the impact of the program on educational opportunities for eligible students, including analyzing admission difficulties and reporting findings to Congress and the Governor. The United States Virgin Islands will analyze admission barriers for students, including caps on out-of-state enrollment, academic requirements, and lack of minority admission programs. Findings will be reported to Congress and the Governor. Islands is authorized to appropriate $10,000,000 annually from non-Federal funds for fiscal years 2015-2020, with additional funds as needed for subsequent years. The funds will remain available until expended. This section will take effect for payments starting on or after January 1, 2015. SEC. 4. GENERAL REQUIREMENTS. The Secretary of Education assigns an adviser to the Governor for program assistance. The Governor can use up to 5% of funds for administrative expenses. Programs under this Act are subject to Inspector General review. The Governor can accept donations for Act implementation. The Governor can establish rules to adjust maximum student amounts for eligible students transferring between institutions under this Act.
